tossups.question: Artists from this modern-day country mass-produced artworks dubbed “Madonneri” that inspired a Giovanni Bellini painting of a baby Christ with a golden apple. A “shadow painter” from this country prefigured Italian chiaroscuro with his dark shading. An artist [emphasize] born in this modern-day country may have inspired the layout of Les Demoiselles d’Avignon (“lay duh-mwah-ZELL dah-veen-YON”) with a painting depicting flailing nudes behind an outstretched St. John. That artist born in this country depicted (*) Saints Stephen and Augustine carrying the body of a local official as his soul rises to heaven in another painting. For 10 points, Spanish friends of the creator of The Opening of the Fifth Seal and The Burial of the Count of Orgaz nicknamed him for being from what country?
tossups.answer: Greece [or Hellas; or the Hellenic Republic; prompt El Greco] (The second line is Apollodorus.)
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Painting - European to 1600> ~26074~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: It’s not a rifle, but a “Winchester” object resembling this other object was used for one of the costumed jousting events named for it in Europe. A violent Yuletide quarrel led a Cornishman to create this portable object, over which loyalty oaths were sworn during the feast of Pentecost. This object is engraved with golden names by an archbishop’s blessing. A white deer is chased around this object by a hound during a royal wedding. (*) Judas’s betrayal is memorialized through this object’s Siege Perilous, which is claimed by Galahad before the start of the Grail quest. Leodegrance gifted this object, whose shape symbolized the equality of Arthur’s vassals. For 10 points, Lancelot was one of the many knights of what object?
tossups.answer: Round Table [accept Knights of the Round Table; prompt on table; prompt on seats or sieges or chairs by asking “what object did they surround?”]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - World Mythology> ~27180~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: In 2023, the International African American Museum opened in this state’s Gadsden’s Wharf. After its legislature closed his school, Daniel Payne left this state and joined the AME Church. In this state, a group of mainly Congolese slaves chanted “Liberty” while being led by Cato in the largest British colonial slave revolt. A failed slave revolt on Bastille Day in this state was planned by a man who purchased his freedom with his lottery winnings, (*) Denmark Vesey. The Stono Rebellion occurred in this state. In the Antebellum period, this state had the largest proportion of Black to white residents due to its rice and indigo plantations. For 10 points, name this state which had slave markets in Charleston.
tossups.answer: South Carolina [or SC]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - American - Pre-1865> ~27791~ <Editor: Arjun Nageswaran

tossups.question: In a blank verse epic by this author, some of the 99 suitors encounter the Ogre of Endless Tears while questing to find a cure for Warigia’s (“wah-REE-gee-ah’s”) disability. After dropping out of the University of Leeds, this author wrote a novel centered around the proverb “that which bites you is in your own clothing.” That novel by this author centers on a character who is reluctant to give a speech because of his guilt from betraying Kihika. A different novel by this author concludes with the teacher Munira burning down a (*) brothel in Ilmorog. This author explained his decision to stop writing in English in the essay “Decolonizing the Mind.” For 10 points, name this Kenyan author of A Grain of Wheat and Petals of Blood.
tossups.answer: Ngugi wa Thiong’o (“GOO-gee wah thee-ON-go”) [or James Ngugi] (The lead-in is The Perfect Nine.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~28556~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: The 2023 discovery of these proteins’ N-terminal helix-loop-helix-loop-helix motif in Bdellovibrio (“DELL-oh-VIH-bree-oh”) finally confirmed that bacteria make them. Post-translational “marks” on these proteins like K9me3 (“K nine M E three”) are detected by ChIP-seq (“chip-seek”). Unless they are amidated, these proteins provide the attractive electrostatic potential that holds together the 30-nanometer fiber. Lysines are alternately (*) acetylated and de-acetylated in the “code” of these proteins during genomic imprinting. The tails of these proteins are rich in basic amino acids that neutralize the negative charge of a sugar-phosphate backbone. These proteins form octamers at the core of a nucleosome. For 10 points, name these proteins that DNA wraps around in chromatin.
tossups.answer: histones
tossups.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~27618~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: A refugee from this government known as Queen Monique set off a craze for wearing pink in China. Because this government destroyed almost all cameras, the 2013 documentary The Missing Picture used stop-motion animation. The first man charged by the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts for actions taken during this government’s reign was Comrade Duch (“DOO-ik”). After declaring a (*) “Year Zero,” this government sent New People to “interrogation centers,” which housed supporters of the exiled king Sihanouk (“see-hah-nook”). This government turned a high school into a notorious death camp at S-21, which continued to torture prisoners even as the Vietnamese Army invaded. For 10 points, name this government headed by Pol Pot that ruled Cambodia.
tossups.answer: Khmer Rouge [or Khmêr Krâhâm; or Democratic Kampuchea; prompt on Cambodian government or Pol Pot administration before mentioned; prompt on the Khmer government] (“Khmer” is sometimes used as shorthand for the Khmer Rouge.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Asian> ~25719~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

tossups.question: In an essay about this short story, George Saunders compares its awkward narrator to Dwight Schrute to explain the skaz tradition. This story ends by observing that “such things happen in this world; rarely, but they do.” In this story, a man writes a letter accusing Madame Podtochina of cursing him because he won’t marry her daughter. In this story, a man wanders around St. Isaac’s (*) Bridge trying to dispose of this story’s title object, which he later learns has become a state councilor. The barber Ivan Yakovlevich finds this story’s title object in a loaf of bread, before Major Kovalyov tries to reattach it to his face. For 10 points, name this Nikolai Gogol short story about a missing body part.
tossups.answer: “The Nose” [or “Nos”]
tossups.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - European - Short Fiction> ~28879~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

tossups.question: In 2022, police seized a weapons cache in this province’s village of Coutts from protestors who had shut down a border crossing. John Vaillant’s 2023 book Fire Weather details how residents of “man camps” in this province reacted to the YMM Fire. This province explored “Wexit” under the leadership of Jason Kenney. Kate Beaton’s memoir Ducks chronicled Maritime migrants who took jobs working in this province’s boomtown of (*) Fort McMurray. This province sparred with a western neighbor over an expansion to the Trans Mountain Pipeline, a project that services this province’s Athabasca Oil Sands. For 10 points, name this Canadian province whose government often clashes with its more liberal western neighbor, British Columbia.
tossups.answer: Alberta
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Current Events - World> ~27716~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: A combined form of this quantity equals one-half for phase space quadratures. States with a value for this quantity below that of the ground state have elliptical phase space distributions that appear “squeezed.” A bound on a combined form of this quantity equals one-half times the norm of the expectation value of a (*) commutator of two operators. This quantity for an operator equals the square root of the difference between its expectation value squared and the square of its expectation value. Because the product of this quantity for x and p is bounded below by h-bar over two, one can never simultaneously know the position and momentum of a particle. For 10 points, name this quantity described in a principle derived by Heisenberg.
tossups.answer: uncertainty [accept standard deviation or variance; accept answers describing a lower bound on a product of two uncertainties or a lower bound on uncertainty; accept standard deviation or variance in place of “uncertainty” in relation to lower bounds; prompt on sigma or sigma-squared] (The lead-in describes the lower bound in the generalized uncertainty principle for a pair of phase space quadratures.)
tossups.metadata: Forrest Weintraub, Science - Physics> ~28069~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: This film features split-second flashes of a make-up test for its lead actress with a pale face and red eyes. A scene in this film of a woman walking home is set to Mike Oldfield’s song “Tubular Bells.” The painting Empire of Light inspired a scene in this film in which a character played by Max von Sydow is illuminated under a street light. The author of this film’s source novel, William Blatty, chose its director (*) William Friedkin. In this film’s finale, Damien throws himself out a window and down a flight of stairs to his death. Priests in this film chant “The power of Christ compels you!” at Pazuzu, a spirit who spins Regan’s head backward. For 10 points, name this 1973 film about a girl possessed by a demon.
tossups.answer: The Exorcist
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Film> ~27153~ <Editor: Ganon Evans

tossups.question: A character created by this author has a conversation with Cordelia while painting a house about to be demolished. In a novel by this author, a woman exclaims “Thank God!” after learning that her son died from falling off the horse Thunderclap. One of this author’s characters, who becomes a missionary in a Tunisian monastery after the death of Kurt, carries around the teddy bear (*) Aloysius (“al-oo-WISH-us”). The protagonist of a novel by this author becomes trapped in a Brazilian jungle by Mr. Todd and is forced to read Dickens. In a novel by this author, Julia Flyte is convinced by her father’s deathbed conversion to break off a plan to marry Charles Ryder. For 10 points, name this author of A Handful of Dust and Brideshead Revisited.
tossups.answer: Evelyn Waugh [or Arthur Evelyn St. John Waugh]
tossups.metadata: Chandler West, Literature - British - Long Fiction> ~27770~ <Editor: Jim Fan

tossups.question: In this piece’s romantic third movement, the clarinet and flute play rising and falling 26- and 32-note tuplets. This piece opens with the low brass playing a stern fortissimo theme starting with the notes “E, down to B, D” that is later tamed by the other main theme. Cellos play wide arpeggios to emulate rocking waves in this piece’s last movement, which depicts a festival and (*) shipwreck. The harp accompanies a sinuous, triplet-based, high violin solo in a theme representing this piece’s title character. For 10 points, “The Young Prince and the Young Princess” and “The Sea and Sinbad’s Ship” are movements of, what symphonic suite by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov titled for the narrator of the Arabian Nights?
tossups.answer: Scheherazade (“sheh-HAIR-uh-zahd”)
tossups.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Music - Romantic> ~27655~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

tossups.question: Conflict with JEDEC standards for this hardware component caused a company co-founded by Mark Horowitz to sue many of its competitors before losing market dominance in the aughts. This component can be composed of a grid of word lines and bit lines connected to sense amplifiers. A DIMM (“DIM”) holds two instances of this component “in-line.” In 2020, a new alignment key for this component’s 288 pins was released with the fifth generation of its “double data rate,” or (*) DDR5. Heat sinks lay flush with “sticks” of this component. Primary storage is typically implemented with this component, in contrast to secondary storage in the hard drive. For 10 points, name this hardware component that temporarily stores volatile data.
tossups.answer: RAM [or DRAM or SDRAM or SRAM or random access memory or dynamic RAM or synchronous dynamic RAM or static random access memory or RAM sticks; prompt on memory storage or memory module; prompt on storage until read; reject “SRAM” or “static RAM”] (Mark Horowitz co-founded Rambus, Inc.)
tossups.metadata: David Bass, Science - Computer Science> ~28581~ <Editor: David Bass

tossups.question: This type of event allows the “Pandas” (“PAHN-dhuhs”) to update the vahis (“VAH-hees”), the world’s largest collection of family trees. The twelve jyotirlinga (“jyoh-TEER-lin-gah”) act as centers for this activity, a designation shared by Badrinath, Dwarka, and the other two Char Dham designated for this activity by Adi Shankara. The revolution of Jupiter every twelve years coincides with four of these events. Legendarily, some of these events occur at the places where the devas and demons spilled the (*) amrita elixir. Tirthas are centers for these events known as yatra. During one of these events called the Kumbh Mela, visitors enter sacred waters for purification. For 10 points, name these religious events during which people travel to sacred sites like the Ganges.
tossups.answer: pilgrimages [accept yatra until read; prompt on general descriptions such as processions or long walks or religious travel; prompt on festival or celebration]
tossups.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Hinduism> ~27182~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

tossups.question: The fifteen “Proven Companions” of this battle’s victor are the only people known to have fought for its winning side. The night before this battle, the losing side camped on Caldbec Hill near a “hoar apple tree” before moving to Senlac Hill the next day. This battle’s losing commander died alongside his brothers Gyrth and Leofwine during it. This battle’s victor landed at (*) Pevensey briefly before it and was crowned later the same year on Christmas Day. Bishop Odo commissioned an artwork that depicts this battle’s loser dying from an arrow in his eye. The Bayeux (“bye-YOO”) Tapestry depicts Harold Godwinson’s death during, for 10 points, what 1066 CE victory for William the Conqueror?
tossups.answer: Battle of Hastings
tossups.metadata: Anthony Troullier, History - European - Middle Ages> ~27591~ <Editor: Ganon Evans

tossups.question: This object is described as a “red hell” whose plunge “into that blackness” is called the “material counterpart” of a man’s “monomaniac soul.” This object is lined with teeth and has small holes in its floor so that one character can maneuver it comfortably. This object, which is owned by Bildad and Peleg, has a (*) “gold coin from Quito” nailed into it by a character with a lightning-shaped scar on his face. This vessel encounters a similar one named the Rachel. In a prophecy told by Fedallah, this vessel is a hearse made from “American wood.” A character uses a coffin carved by a Polynesian harpooner named Queequeg to survive this ship’s destruction. For 10 points, name this whaling ship from Moby Dick.
tossups.answer: the Pequod [accept specific descriptions of the ship such as the mast of the Pequod or deck of the Pequod; prompt on descriptions such as the ship from Moby Dick; prompt on a ship or whaling ship or a boat; prompt on mast or deck by asking “of what specific object?”]
tossups.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Long Fiction> ~27518~ <Editor: Chandler West

tossups.question: This quantity appears in both the numerator and the denominator in the usual definition of the Lerner index. Unlike in the Cournot (“core-NOH”) model, this quantity is explicitly chosen in the Bertrand model. The Slutsky equation takes the derivative with respect to this quantity of the Marshallian demand, giving terms corresponding to the income and substitution effects. Menu costs primarily contribute to this quantity’s (*) “stickiness.” Firms in perfect competition are described as “takers” of this quantity. Government-imposed “floors” on this quantity can result in surpluses if they are above this quantity’s equilibrium value. For 10 points, supply and demand curves plot quantity sold against what quantity measured in dollars?
tossups.answer: price [prompt on P; prompt on wages]
tossups.metadata: Joseph Krol, Social Science - Economics> ~26044~ <Editor: Vincent Du

tossups.question: A student loan system established in Oxford in 1240 relied on one of these objects named for Saint Frideswide. The Lane Company gave “hope” versions of these objects to girls graduating high school. Renaissance brides were given a type of these objects called a cassone (“cass-OH-nay”), one of which can be seen open in The Venus of Urbino. They’re not skeletons, but one of these physical objects is found after Legrand realizes that an old man dropped the title (*) insect through the wrong eye socket in Edgar Allen Poe’s “The Gold-Bug.” Another of these objects owned by Captain Flint is sought by Hispaniola cabin boy Jim Hawkins. For 10 points, name these objects, one of which is buried on an island in a Robert Louis Stevenson novel.
tossups.answer: treasure chest [accept buried treasure chest or hope chest or marriage chest or sea chest; accept trunk; prompt on treasure]
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~27735~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: During hydrotreatment, this element is removed from hydrocarbons using Raney (“ranny”) nickel, which allows refineries to reform naphtha (“NAP-tha”) fuels. Gypsum is made by scrubbing oxides of this element out of flue gas. Oxides of this element are injected into the stratosphere to form aerosols in a solar geoengineering strategy inspired by volcanic winters. This nonmetal is at the octahedral center of the most potent (*) greenhouse gas. On Earth, this element’s oxidation state cycles between minus-two, in minerals like galena and pyrite, up to plus-six, after it is oxidized by oceanic chemo·lithotrophs. Polluting oxides of nitrogen or this element produce acid rain. For 10 points, a gas containing what element makes bogs smell eggy?
tossups.answer: sulfur [or sulphur; or S]
tossups.metadata: Briana Magin, Science - Chemistry> ~17268~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

tossups.question: Description acceptable. During the English Civil War, William Dowsing was nicknamed for vigorously enforcing this policy as per a law that called out rood lofts. A decree by Yazid II may have inspired a later policy of this type whose end in 843 CE is celebrated on the Feast of Orthodoxy. A “fury” of this policy took place during Germany’s Bildersturm in the 16th century. One of these policies was applied to the Temples of Bel and Baalshamin in (*) Palmyra in 2015. Emperor Leo III began a period of applying this policy in the Byzantine Empire based on a prohibition in the Ten Commandments. A palace in Nimrud was bulldozed as part of one of these policies by ISIL. For 10 points, name this policy that prohibits the use of religious images.
tossups.answer: iconoclasm [accept answers like anti-idolatry policies or anti-graven image policies or Islamic aniconism or destroying art or destroying relics; prompt on destroying temples or destroying non-Islamic religious objects; reject answers about “policies prohibiting the depiction of Muhammad”] (William Dowsing was nicknamed Smasher Dowsing.)
tossups.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~25724~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

tossups.question: Deformities of this structure are measured by the Cobb angle. When it’s not in the lungs, tuberculosis infects this structure in Pott’s disease and collapses its gelatinous nuclei pulposi, which are surrounded by fibrous annuli. This structure’s C-shaped bend alternates between lordotic and kyphotic. This structure bifurcates in a birth defect often caused by folate deficiency. In order, this structure’s (*) bones are labeled C1 to C7, then T1 to T12, L1 to L5, and S1 to S5. Floating ribs are attached to this structure but not the sternum. In a lumbar puncture, CSF is tapped from a cavity inside this structure. For 10 points, stacks of vertebrae and discs form what flexible structure which encloses a cord of nervous tissue?
tossups.answer: spine [or spinal column; accept spinal cord; accept vertebral column or vertebrae until “vertebrae” is read]
tossups.metadata: Sinecio Morales, Science - Biology> ~28778~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Alan Garner argued that this person’s suicide by biting into an apple laced with cyanide was inspired by Snow White. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this person who pleaded guilty to indecency charges in 1952. A 2017 law named for this person pardoned those prosecuted for homosexuality in Britain.

The Wolfenden Committee first suggested decriminalizing homosexuality after the 1954 arrest of a member of this family. A much earlier woman who married into this family recorded how Turkish women opened blisters on each other.
The largest LGBTQ+ rights organization in Britain is named after this New York gay bar, where a series of 1969 riots launched the US’s gay rights movement.
answers: Montagu [accept Edward Douglas-Scott-Montagu; accept Mary Wortley Montagu; prompt on Pierrepont with “what family did she marry into?”]
Stonewall Inn [or Bonnie’s Stonewall Inn; accept Stonewall Equality Ltd]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, History - Cross, Historiography, and Miscellaneous> ~22587~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: In a novel from this country, Bentu exiles his wife and son to Europe after suspecting that his wife cheated on him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country that is the setting of Dom Casmurro. A “Posthumous Memoir” from this country documents Brás Cubas’s (“BRAHS coo-BAHS”) obsession over a poultice.
Dom Casmurro frequently draws parallels to this tragic Shakespeare character who is fooled by Iago into suspecting Desdemona of infidelity.
Joana (“ZHOO-ahn-ah”) meditates on her indifference to her husband cheating on her in Near to the Wild Heart, the debut novel by this Ukrainian-born Brazilian author of The Passion According to G.H.
answers: Brazil [or Brasil or Federative Republic of Brazil or República Federativa do Brasil] (The above works are all by Machado de Assis.)
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Literature - World and Miscellaneous> ~23318~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: The drying up of this body of water has significantly affected the economy of the autonomous region of Kara·kal·pak·stan. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this lake between Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan that has shrunk significantly since the 1960s.
Cultivation of this crop is the main industry in Karakalpakstan. Carl Linnaeus named the Gossypium barbadense or Sea Island variety of this crop because it was originally found in Barbados.

More recently, farmers in Karakalpakstan have taken to growing this crop, which grows well in salted soil. This crop’s mucokinetic effects are why the plurality of Icelandic candy contains it as an ingredient.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Geography - World> ~22119~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: Oxygen gas was rare during a period known as the “Boring [this many years].” For 10 points each:
parts: Give this number of years denoted “G·a,” or “giga annum.”

In the Canfield Ocean model, the deep ocean has this property due to the lack of oxygen gas during the Boring Billion. Water that is anoxic and sulfidic has this property, whose name derives from Greek for “hospitality.”

Euxinic conditions would have to persist up to this layer in a Canfield Ocean in order to support necessary anoxygenic production. This upper layer of the ocean is typically conflated with the epipelagic zone.
answers: one billion years [accept ten-to-the-ninth years; accept the Boring Billion]
photic zone [or euphotic zone; prompt on sunlight zone by asking “what is its scientific name?”] (Johnston et al. 2009 argues for the necessity of anoxygenic photosynthesis in the Canfield Ocean.)
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Science - Earth> ~23830~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: Josef Lada made over six hundred illustrations for stories about this character. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “good” character, who steals a dog from a colonel after being told to find a dog for a lieutenant. This character is almost executed by General Fink von Finkenstein.
Jaroslav Hašek’s (“YAH-roh-slav HAH-shek’s”) novel The Good Soldier Švejk was written in this non-French language, as was Milan Kundera’s The Unbearable Lightness of Being.

After Hašek’s death, this author wrote a play in which Švejk meets Hitler. This author wrote the libretto for Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny and outlined the distancing effect in his theory of epic theater.
answers: The Good Soldier Švejk (“sh’VAKE”) [or Švejka or Schweik or Shveyk or Schwejk; accept Osudy dobrého vojáka Švejka za světové války]
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Literature - European - Other> ~23055~ <Editor: Jaimie Carlson

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about references to Exodus 34:6 (“chapter 34, verse 6”), in which God reveals his name and the merciful aspects of his character to Moses, for 10 points each.
parts: God quotes the Exodus verse in asking Judah to repent in the wake of invading locusts in Chapter 2 of this book. Sequentially, this is the second minor prophet book in most Bibles.
Levites invoke the Exodus verse in Nehemiah 9 (“chapter 9”) during a prayer of corporate repentance after rebuilding the walls of this sacred capital of Judah.

King Hezekiah references the Exodus verse in 2 Chronicles (“second Chronicles”) when reinstituting this holiday, which commemorates a time when the Angel of Death avoided doors marked with lamb’s blood.
bonuses.metadata: Jon Suh, RMP - Hebrew Bible> ~22114~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: This character has been played by men and women, like André de Shields and Lillias White. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this narrator of a 2019 musical by Anaïs (“uh-NAY-iss”) Mitchell. This character introduces characters like Orpheus and Eurydice in the opening number “Road to Hell.”
This musical’s gender-neutral role of the Leading Player has been played by Ben Vereen and Patina Miller. The title character of this 1972 Stephen Schwartz musical sings “Corner of the Sky.”
In 2018, this composer and lyricist worked with director Marianne Elliot to genderswap his musical Company. He also wrote Into the Woods and Sweeney Todd.
bonuses.metadata: Ivvone Zhou, Fine Arts - Miscellaneous> ~23335~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. This quantity can vary between two and three across cells in the human body after a di·gynic or di·spermic fertilization. For 10 points each:
parts: Give either the six-letter name or a description of this quantity, which is three for cells in the endosperm and alternates between one and two in the generations of an angiosperm.
Regardless of ploidy, the total chromosome count in any human cell should be multiples of what odd integer, the haploid chromosome count?
69-chromosome zygotes immediately split into diploid and triploid lineages in these cells, the first products of zygotic cleavage. They divide to form the morula.
answers: ploidy [or the number of copies of each chromosome in a cell; accept copies or copy number of DNA; accept any answers that include the words haploid, diploid, or triploid; prompt on n; reject “number of chromosomes”]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Biology> ~22183~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: Ethnomycologists study how ancient Greeks may have mixed these organisms into kykeon during the Eleusinian Mysteries. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these capped, spore-bearing organisms called “food of the gods” by ancient Egyptians.
Mushrooms may have killed the Roman emperor Jovian while campaigning against this empire. Shapur II ruled this major enemy of third-century Rome.

The crackpot historian and ethnomycologist John M. Allegro was fired from Manchester University for writing a book titled for “The Sacred Mushroom and [one of these objects].” Heraclius recovered one of these objects after it was taken during a 614 CE sack by Khosrow II.
answers: Sassanid Empire [or Sasanian Empire; or Neo-Persian Empire; prompt on Empire of the Iranians or Persia or Persian Empire]
cross [accept True Cross; accept The Sacred Mushroom and the Cross] (John Allegro alleged that Jesus was actually symbolic of the mushroom Amanita muscaria.)
bonuses.metadata: Abhinav Rachakonda, History - European - Classical> ~23317~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: Diodorus Siculus relates a reinterpretation of this figure as a powerful shepherd who guards a flock of golden-fleeced sheep. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this hundred-headed beast represented by the constellation Draco. Vase paintings tend to depict this unsleeping beast coiled around an apple tree.
Ladon guards the immortality-granting golden apples in this garden, whose eponymous daughters of Atlas are the source of the sunset’s golden light.
Ladon’s still-twitching corpse is later encountered by this band of adventurers led by Jason.
answers: Ladon [prompt on, BUT DO NOT REVEAL, Drakon Hesperian or Hesperian Dragon or the dragon that guards the Garden of the Hesperides or the dragon that guards the golden apples of immortality]
bonuses.metadata: Kevin Thomas, RMP - Greco-Roman Mythology> ~22632~ <Editor: Kevin Thomas

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher praised a “useless” tree that survives because it is too old and gnarled to be cut down for timber. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 4th-century BCE Chinese philosopher who questioned whether he was a man dreaming of being a butterfly or vice versa.
Zhuāngzǐ was a member of this school of thought, which emphasizes effortless action called wu wei and was legendarily founded by Lǎozǐ (“LAO-tzuh”).

Zhuāngzǐ’s discussion of people like “Shu the Discombobulated” has led scholars like Helen De Cruz to read him as a philosopher of this concept. Rosemarie Garland-Thomson pioneered feminist approaches to this concept, which is decentered by using “people-first language.”
answers: disability [prompt on related terms like chronic illness or impairment or being handicapped]
bonuses.metadata: Jordan Brownstein, RMP - Philosophy> ~22149~ <Editor: Vincent Du

bonuses.leadin: A 1946 Ted Brown adaptation of this play with an all-Black cast had to remove lesbian undertones for the Federal Theatre Project. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play in which a woman pledges to not “crouch like a lioness on a cheese grater” in an oath over a Thasian wine jug.
The all-Black “Voodoo” Macbeth was put on by this founder of the Mercury Theatre, who also directed the controversial pro-labor musical The Cradle Will Rock.
This lesbian author pioneered Black actors in mainstream Broadway roles with a cast including Sidney Poitier (“pwa-tee-ay”) and Ruby Dee for her play A Raisin in the Sun.
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Literature - American - Drama> ~20878~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: The artist Cecilia Vicuña often hangs artworks named for these objects from ceilings. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects that were used for record-keeping and other purposes by the Inca.
Prior to the Inca, quipus (“KEE-poo’s”) were used by a kingdom often named for this city. The Inca themselves made this Andean city their capital.
The Inca used quipu to keep track of the stock of this foodstuff. Along with dried meat known as char’ki, the Inca kept reserves of these freezed-dried potatoes in case of famines.
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, History - World - Latin American> ~22418~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran

bonuses.leadin: A German artist with this first name depicted a woman stepping out of the stomach of a wolf in her sculpture Rapture. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this first name, which appeared with “de Montparnasse” in the stage name of a model who had violin holes painted on her back for photographs by Man Ray.
Kiki Smith created a silicon bronze sculpture of this woman with flayed skin and dragging a chain. Donatello created a realist sculpture of this “penitent” woman made of wood.
Another Man Ray photo of Kiki de Montparnasse shows her playing with some of these African artworks whose abstract features and elongated proportions inspired Cubist artists.
answers: Kiki [accept Kiki Smith or Kiki de Montparnasse; prompt on Alice or Alice Prin with “what was her stage name?”] (The photograph is Le Violon d’Ingres.)
Mary Magdalene [accept Magdalena or Madeleine or Mary of Magdala; accept The Penitent Magdalene; prompt on Mary; reject the “Virgin Mary”]
bonuses.metadata: Ganon Evans, Fine Arts - Sculpture> ~23630~ <Editor: Chandler West

bonuses.leadin: Theodor Wulf found initial evidence for these particles with an electrometer atop the Eiffel Tower. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these “astroparticles” that reach Earth at near-light speeds. Victor Hess ascended three miles in a balloon to discover these “cosmic” particles.
C. T. R. Wilson’s research atop Ben Nevis inspired his invention of these particle detectors in which charged particles leave paths as they move through supersaturated vapor.
César Lattes’s placement of emulsion plates atop Chacaltaya was key in the discovery of these lightest hadrons. Charged examples of these mesons typically decay into a muon and muon neutrino.
answers: pions [or pi mesons or pi plus mesons or pi minus mesons]
bonuses.metadata: Joseph Krol, Science - Physics> ~23819~ <Editor: David Bass

bonuses.leadin: A union of people in this profession backed Ronald Reagan in the 1980 presidential election and received the most generous contract ever offered to a government employee union. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this profession whose workers nevertheless staged a 1981 PATCO strike where many were fired.

Barbara Kopple’s film American Dream chronicles another Reagan-era strike of workers at a Spam factory for Hormel Foods in this state, whose picketers included this state’s future senator Paul Wellstone.
In 1988, writers in this industry went on strike. Reagan himself led SAG (“sag”), a guild of workers in this industry, during the blacklist era.
answers: air traffic controllers [or ATC; accept air controllers or flight controllers; prompt on controllers; prompt on aviation officials]
film industry [accept answers like movies or Hollywood or television; prompt on entertainment or acting or actors]

bonuses.leadin: One poem describes a person from this place whose “grandmother was a Warlock” and “had a cat named Flo,” and suggests that he was unjustly blamed. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this place, the origin of a person who supposedly interrupted a poet while he was on opium, causing one poem that mentions a “stately pleasure-dome” to only be 54 lines long.
This author was allegedly interrupted by the Person from Porlock while writing “Kubla Khan.”

A poet with this last name implores “I am hungry to be interrupted” in “Thoughts about the Person from Porlock.” Another author with this last name described a character who meets Clara Bowden after failing to gas himself in a car.
answers: Smith [accept Stevie Smith; or Florence Margaret Smith; or Zadie Smith; or Sadie Adeline Smith] (The unnamed novel is White Teeth.)
bonuses.metadata: Jaimie Carlson, Literature - British - Poetry> ~22156~ <Editor: Jim Fan

bonuses.leadin: Suffragette Nellie McClung lectured on a type of “madness” that afflicted people living in isolation in this general location. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this flat location once called the Great American Desert. Nebraska and the Dakotas are generally included within this location.
An author of this ethnicity addressed Prairie Madness in his novel Giants in the Earth. The 1970 Nobel Peace Prize was won by a man of this ethnicity called “The Father of the Green Revolution.”
“Prairie Madness” was one reason that many people failed to complete a five-year residency requirement of this legislation. This 1862 law attracted Black Exodusters to Kansas.
answers: Great Plains [or the prairie or Western Plains; accept Prairie Madness; prompt on plains]
Norwegian-American [prompt on Scandinavian-American or Norse or Nordic] (The author was Ole Rolvaag. The scientist was Norman Borlaug.)
bonuses.metadata: Michael Bentley, Other - Other Academic and General Knowledge> ~22860~ <Editor: Michael Bentley

bonuses.leadin: This symphony features parts for the ondes Martenot (“AHND mar-teh-NOH”) and piano, which was played by Yvonne Loriod (“lo-ree-OH”) at its 1949 premiere. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ten-movement work inspired by the myth of Tristan and Isolde.
This French composer of the Turangalîla-Symphonie wrote and premiered his Quartet for the End of Time while interred at a Nazi POW camp.

Two movements of Quartet for the End of Time “praise” the “eternity” and “immortality” of this figure. Songs addressed to this figure include the Bach chorale “Joy of Man’s Desiring” and the carol “Away in a Manger.”
bonuses.metadata: Ethan Ashbrook, Fine Arts - Music - 1900 to 1970> ~23229~ <Editor: Ivvone Zhou

bonuses.leadin: Chemists inexplicably draw vectors on these systems in the opposite direction as physicists. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these physical systems. A “permanent” one established at a carbonyl (“car-buh-NEEL”) bond is responsible for the intermolecular attractive force between two ketones.
Since this is a chemistry bonus, the carbonyl dipole moment points from carbon to oxygen, in the direction of increasing this quantity. Oxygen rates 3.5 on this quantity’s Pauling scale.

If it reacts with this biological carbene, a carbonyl’s dipole moment vector flips. Cells need the pyro·phosphate form of this coenzyme, a nitrogen-sulfur ylide (“ILL-id”), to turn pyruvate into acetyl-CoA (“uh-SEE-till coh A”).
answers: thiamine [or vitamin B1; or thiamine pyrophosphate or TPP; prompt on vitamin B or B vitamins; prompt on vitamins]
bonuses.metadata: Adam Silverman, Science - Chemistry> ~22799~ <Editor: Adam Silverman

bonuses.leadin: This organization was responsible for the disappearance of more than one hundred leftists as part of Operation Colombo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this secret police organization. Orlando Letelier was assassinated by this organization by a car bomb outside the Irish Embassy in Washington D.C.
The DINA secret police operated under this country’s dictator Augusto Pinochet.

Within DINA, Eugenio Berríos was tasked by Pinochet to manufacture this substance on a large scale as part of Project Andreya. Aum Shinrikyo carried out their Tokyo subway attack using this nerve agent.
bonuses.metadata: Hari Parameswaran, History - World - Latin American> ~13484~ <Editor: Hari Parameswaran
